section.p: The water-balanced railway basically operates like a huge balance, using the difference in weight between the two carriages to transport passengers up and down a hillside 30 metres in height.

The carriages are made of timber and steel so that they are light and strong. Underneath each one is a ballast tank, which carries up to 1,600 litres of water. The carriages run along 53 metres of parallel steel track and are linked by steel cables. These go around a large drum at the top of the slope.

When one carriage is at the top of the hill, the other is at the bottom. The ballast tank underneath the top carriage is filled with water from a reservoir so as to make it slightly heavier than the lower carriage. Due to this imbalance, the top one begins to roll down the hill, pulling the other one up. A computer control system weighs each carriage in order to gauge exactly how much water is needed to make them move. Speed is controlled by means of a braking system built into the drum at the top. This consists of a hydraulic pump, which slows the drum down if it is turning too fast, causing the carriages to reduce speed. Each time this happens, the system compresses gas in special cylinders. As a result, some of the energy of braking is stored. This can later be used to pump a proportion of the water back up to the reservoir. Consequently, some energy is recycled.
The water-balanced railway is an excellent example of how renewable energy sources can be used to power a transport system.
